target_words.definition: Treatment that helps a person feel better in body or mind.
A short, planned period of time for a task or activity.
A good or helpful result you get from something.

items.question: Which of these unusual real-world therapy ideas has been offered in Japan?

correct_option.title: Crying Therapy
correct_option.text: Some Japanese events invite people to cry together while a guide helps them release stress during a short session.
correct_option.reason: If you love a strange but gentle way to feel a benefit fast, this emotional idea sounds perfect.

distractors.title: Soap-Bubble Therapy
distractors.text: Visitors breathe toward giant soap bubbles to ‘blow worries away’ in a colorful room.
distractors.reason: It sounds peaceful and easy, and bubbles always look magical, so it feels believable.

distractors.title: Umbrella Singing Therapy
distractors.text: People sing into umbrellas to hear calming echoes that ‘clean the mind’.
distractors.reason: The picture is funny and charming, and echo sounds can feel relaxing to many people.

items.evidence_text: Japan really has crying therapy events where people release stress by crying together in a guided session. Many say it gives a fast emotional benefit.

target_words.definition: A strong feeling of worry or fear about something.
A feeling that you can do something well or succeed.
A soft, kind way of behaving.

items.question: Which real animal is used in some airports to help calm people’s anxiety?

correct_option.title: Therapy Pigs
correct_option.text: Some U.S. airports have trained pigs that walk around and greet passengers to help reduce anxiety.
correct_option.reason: A friendly pig with surprising gentleness can really lift your confidence before a flight.

distractors.title: Airport Hedgehogs
distractors.text: Small hedgehogs sit in tiny baskets, and travelers are encouraged to ‘slow down’ while watching them.
distractors.reason: They look peaceful and cute, so it feels like they could calm anyone.

distractors.title: Soothing Llamas
distractors.text: Llamas walk the hall to ‘share calm energy’ with nervous passengers.
distractors.reason: Llamas seem gentle and wise in stories, so the idea sounds almost true.

items.evidence_text: Some airports, including San Francisco, use therapy pigs to comfort travelers and lower anxiety. Their gentleness helps people feel more confidence.

target_words.definition: The ability to do things by yourself without help.
Unable to move part or all of the body.

items.question: Which real invention was created to help paralyzed people gain more independence?

correct_option.title: Mind-Control Wheelchair
correct_option.text: Scientists developed a wheelchair that moves when the user thinks of directions.
correct_option.reason: It sounds high-tech but real, and it directly supports independence.

distractors.title: Magnetic Floor Boots
distractors.text: Metal floors and special boots help users ‘walk’ with controlled magnets under the building.
distractors.reason: Magnets feel futuristic, so many people might accept them quickly.

distractors.title: Voice-Controlled Balance Suit
distractors.text: A full-body suit reacts to commands like ‘stand’ or ‘turn’ to help with movement.
distractors.reason: Voice control is common today, so this idea seems possible.

items.evidence_text: Researchers have built mind-control wheelchairs using brain signals. These devices help paralyzed users move more freely and gain independence.

target_words.definition: To teach someone how to do something.
A building where horses are kept.

items.question: Which of these real horse-related jobs sometimes requires workers to instruct children during farm tours?

correct_option.title: Stable Tour Guides
correct_option.text: Some farms hire guides who show visitors around the stable and instruct kids on horse care.
correct_option.reason: It is everyday work and fits naturally with real stable life.

distractors.title: Saddle Painters
distractors.text: These artists paint colorful saddles and explain color meanings to young visitors.
distractors.reason: Creative jobs exist everywhere, so it feels possible.

distractors.title: Horse Whisper Meter Readers
distractors.text: Workers measure how ‘calm’ a horse is and teach kids to read gentle sounds.
distractors.reason: It has a mystical feeling that can tempt curious players.

items.evidence_text: Many farms offer guided stable tours. Workers really instruct visitors, especially children, on basic horse care and safety.
